texts.definition: The goal of upholding a diegetic commitment to support a person, group, or cause.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of upholding a diegetic commitment to support a person, group, or cause.</style>

The concept of being faithful to other people or abstract causes is often used to explain or initiate actions. In games this can be used to set up the premise for the gameplay so that players have a diegetic motivation for the actions. <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can also become part of gameplay itself if it is possible to go against one's <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style>, typically because the target of one's <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is perceived as having betrayed oneself or that other goals are more compelling.

If the PC becomes the member of Thiefâ€™s Guild in Oblivion (in the Elder Scrolls series), being loyal to the guild requires complying with rules that bans stealing from another member, killing while carrying out a task, and stealing from the poor.

In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crusader%20Kings">Crusader Kings</link></style>, dukes and counts need to put their armies under the control of their king when war occurs to prove their loyalty, and failing to do so provides a reason for civil war.

In the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, the NPCs that accompany the player's character may feel that their <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> have been misused if players behave in certain ways and leave the player's character.

<style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> to each other in relations is included in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style>, since flirted with other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims">Sims</link></style> so it is noticed cause instant reactions.

The presence of a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> or an <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> for the player is needed to use <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style>, since is based on being a diegetic commitment (although the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> might represent an abstract entity such as a civilization or country). Another requirement is to make a decision on whom or what to be faithful to, and here some more possibilities exist. Individual <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> allow personal bonds and the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Linked%20Destinies">Linked Destinies</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> can provide more flexibility in <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and make the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> come into play more naturally in many different places of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20World">Game World</link></style>. Both can be used to require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Maintenance">Social Maintenance</link></style>. The third option is a cause, which from a gameplay perspective can be seen as one way of diegetically presenting <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> can also be used to model temporary <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. A forth option is to make players parts of <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, which have <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> as part of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> of being members of them.

Although the above assumes that it is a player than has the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> towards something, the use of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> allows these <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> to be loyal towards a player (of course, a player can be loyal to his <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> as well). In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can exist as reciprocal relations through the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="symbiotic-player-relations">Symbiotic Player Relations</link></style> that can be mapped to some diegetic representation.

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can either be forced upon the recipient or be voluntary. Enforced <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can either be present from the start or occur as effect of <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> of the game. When there exists a choice between having <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> or not, it is a <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goal</link></style> but can often be shaped into also being a <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Action</link></style> when it is <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that have the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> commitments. Note that <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> may also be defined as either being loyal in all ways possible through gameplay actions or only appearing to be loyal (e.g. embezzling money for personal gain but still supporting one's patrons in all other ways).

The actual requirement of <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is typically to accomplish a goal but this may also include <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> to those opposed whatever one is loyal to. For <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> towards <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, requirements related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Norms">Social Norms</link></style> can easily be added to provide added complexity. There are several ways of introducing challenges to a <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Opposing%20Goals">Opposing Goals</link></style> is probably the most obvious and comes in to forms. One is giving goals to other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in the game so that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> occur and <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals are introduced as a result. The other is giving these <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Opposing%20Goals">Opposing Goals</link></style> to the player himself or herself. This either creates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations in that the player need to choose between different actions that cause <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> in relation to maintaining the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style>, or  require <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> to appear to be maintaining <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Norms">Social Norms</link></style>. When the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> lies towards <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, this can be taken a step further through the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Either%20You%20are%20with%20Me%20or%20against%20Me">Either You are with Me or against Me</link></style>. If the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is directed towards a <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can be used to create a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Dilemma">Social Dilemma</link></style> by the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Requesting%20Support">Requesting Support</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> ends typically occur either with <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for failing to fulfill the goal but can also be consequences of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. Typical appropriate effects when this occurs include becoming an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcasts">Outcast</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitor</link></style> and gaining <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. Providing <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> at the end of a <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is less common but can make sense at the end of a <style="Link"><link="quests">Quest</link></style>. The end of <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can either be a binary change from one game state to another or part of a more complex sub part of the game system, possibly including <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>. The <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crusader%20Kings">Crusader Kings</link></style> are examples of the latter, with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crusader%20Kings">Crusader Kings</link></style> for having detailed bonuses like modifying vassals' loyalty depending on how closely related they are to their liege.
<style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is a diegetic pattern so all aspects of it relate to the game diegesis.

Although the target for the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is not necessary aware of it (which is unavoidable if it is a cause), making it explicit as a promise, rite, or ritual in the game diegesis is a easy way of integrating the description of goals into a game's <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> in the sense that a part of a relation needs to be maintained, and also <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> since failing them typically carried <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can most of the time be maintained simply by avoiding to do actions that would break the agreement and this is especially common for <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> directed to causes in the form of <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. When opposition exists, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Enemies">Mutual Enemies</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> also gives rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style>. When active display of <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is required but other actions can be beneficial as well, <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> can be the cause of <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>. Having several incompatible <style="CurrentLink">Loyalties</style> can in themselves give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> (including <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style> can arise from <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style>, either from wishing not to disappoint or from failing to have shown it and trying to redeem oneself.

When players are giving <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Opposing%20Goals">Opposing Goals</link></style> in relation to some <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> they have, this creates <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> when the <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> is directed towards <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. If it is possible to circumvent the incompatibility of the goals through <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, this instantiates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> in addition. If the actions involved can lead to the consequences of becoming <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcasts">Outcasts</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Loyalty</style> makes these into <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>.
